metadata.case_name: Rashid Khan & Ors. v. State of West Bengal

facts.text: On 16th March, 1993, just before the stroke of mid-night, people in and around B.B. Ganguly Street in the Bow Bazar Area of Calcutta heard deafening sounds emanating from thundering explosions which resulted in total demolition of a building and partial demolition of two other adjacent buildings situated at 267,266 and 268 A, B.B. Ganguly Street. Large number of people were trapped in and buried under the demolished buildings. 69 persons died.

First information report was lodged at Bow Bazar Police Station for alleged commission of offences punishable under Section 120B, 436, 302, 307, 326 of the IPC and Sections 3 and 5 of the Explosive Substances Act, 1908.
Commissioner of Police set up a special investigating team. On investigation 8 persons including the six appellants were found linked with the commission of offences. Arrests were made.

While rescue operations were on there was further explosion on 18.3.1993. The exploded bomb was handed over to the police officer after its examination on the spot by a Military Officer. Pay loader picked up a gunny bag containing 22 live bombs. Afterwards they were defused after examination.
Certain materials were seized by the investigating team from the site of the occurrence and on examination, it was found that nitro-glycerin explosives were involved in the explosion.

Pannalal Jayasora (accused-appellant in Criminal Appeal No. 299/2002) and Mohd. Gulzar (accused-appellant in Criminal Appeal No. 494/2002) were arrested on 29.3.1993 and 13.5.1993 respectively. Their confessional statements were recorded by the magistrates PWs.81 and 82.
Some of the accused persons were also identified by witnesses in the Test Identification Parade.

On 11.6.1993, the Commissioner of Police came to the conclusion that provisions of TADA Act were applicable. Sanction was accorded for prosecution under the said statute. Charge sheet was submitted on 14.6.1993.

Accused filed writ in Calcutta High Court challenging sanction and cognizance under TADA. High Court quashed. Prosecution appealed to Supreme Court, appeal allowed directing Designated Court to proceed: State of West Bengal v. Mohd. Khalid, 1995 1 SCC 684.
Designated Court framed charges under Section 120B, 436/34, 302/34 IPC, Section 3 and 5 of Explosive Act and Section 3(2)(i) and 3(3) of TADA Act.
Out of 165 witnesses examined, star witnesses PW.40 Md. Sabir Natu, PW.67 Santosh Hazra and PW.68 Kristin Chow Kittu proved conspiracy.
Designated Court convicted accused-appellants under Section 120B IPC, Sections 3 and 5 of Explosive Act and Section 3(2)(i) and 3(3) of TADA Act r/w 34 IPC. Acquitted under 302/34 and 436/34 IPC.

Sentences: RI for life + fine Rs.3000 for 3(2)(i) TADA r/w 34; RI 5 years + Rs.500 for 3(3) TADA; RI 10 years + Rs.1000 for S.3 Explosive Act; RI 1 year + Rs.300 for S.5 Explosive Act; RI life + Rs.3000 for 120B IPC.
PW-40 deposed about presence of accused mixing ingredients and manufacturing bombs on 16.3.1993 around 10-10.30 pm, Rashid asking Pannalal to prepare bombs.
PWs 67 and 68 deposed about Rashid, Pannalal and Osman discussing preparation of large number of bombs due to riots in Bombay, to be used if Hindus attack Muslims.

legal_issues.text: Whether the evidence of star witnesses PWs 40,67,68 is reliable despite delay in recording statements and their antecedents.
Whether criminal conspiracy under Section 120B IPC is proved.
Whether confessional statements under Section 164 CrPC of co-accused are admissible and reliable against appellants, and applicability of Sections 10, 30 Evidence Act.
Whether the acts constitute terrorist acts under Sections 3(2)(i), 3(3) TADA, or mere self-defence.
Applicability of Sections 3 and 5 Explosive Substances Act.
Whether non-examination of certain witnesses like Nausad and Osman affects prosecution case.

petitioner_arguments.text: Star witnesses are persons with doubtful antecedents, rowdy elements under thumb of police, deposed falsely. Their evidence suffers from fallacies, embellished statements, delay in recording (two days after incident without explanation).
No reliable evidence of conspiracy. Explosion was accident. No design to commit any act.
Judicial confessions retracted, made under terror, threat, compulsion. Confessions of co-accused not substantive evidence, limited role unless other evidence convincing.
Acts were in self-protection against possible Hindu attack, inspired by Bombay riots where police failed Muslims. Not to spread terror but right of private defence.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: TADA Act inapplicable; right of private defence

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 3 Explosive Act inapplicable as no material they caused explosion. Deceased accused caused it.
Non-examination of independent witnesses like Nausad (owner) and Osman renders prosecution suspect.
Section 10 Evidence Act inapplicable post-explosion/conspiracy over.

respondent_arguments.text: Intention to terrorise people, large quantity explosives/bombs negates self-protection. Motive to spread communal disharmony under cover of self-protection.
Confessions voluntary, recorded after warning, retraction afterthought. Deserve greater acceptability. Fall within Section 10 Evidence Act.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 164 CrPC, Evidence Act Sections 10, 15 TADA

respondent_arguments.text: Delay in witness statements due to chaos, rescue priority. Evidence cogent.
Possession of explosives established, purpose to manufacture bombs for terror. Constructive liability even if others caused explosion.
Prosecution not bound to examine all witnesses; quality over quantity. Non-examined witnesses not material.

court_reasoning.text: Evidence of PWs 40,67,68 reliable after scrutiny. Natural presence as locals, relatives died (PW68). Delay explained by rescue chaos. Not infirm.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Witnesses credible, support prosecution version with confessions.

court_reasoning.text: Criminal conspiracy proved by circumstances, eyewitnesses, confessions. Agreement to do illegal act (manufacture bombs to strike terror) with overt acts. No direct evidence needed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Essence is agreement; proved by direct and circumstantial evidence.

court_reasoning.text: Confessions voluntary, true per magistrates. Retracted after 2 years. Used under Section 30 Evidence Act only to corroborate other evidence, not foundation. Section 10 inapplicable post-arrest as agency ceased.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Approach: First other evidence, then confession for assurance.

court_reasoning.text: Acts to strike terror in people, affect communal harmony. Not self-defence: no apprehension of attack arisen. Preparation/possession of bombs per se illegal, tantamount to terrorising.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Terrorist act: intent to overawe/strike terror beyond ordinary law.

court_reasoning.text: Possession/use of explosives proved. Even if S.3 not, convict under S.4 lesser offence. But life sentence under other counts makes no difference.
Non-examination not fatal; prosecution examined material witnesses. Quality matters.

holdings.text: Evidence of eyewitnesses and confessions establish conspiracy under 120B IPC.
Confessions admissible under Section 30 Evidence Act to corroborate, voluntary and true.
Acts constitute terrorist acts under TADA Sections 3(2)(i), 3(3); not private defence.
Offences under Explosive Act Sections 3,5 proved.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of West Bengal and Anr. v. Mohd. Khalid and Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Allowed prosecution appeal, directed trial under TADA.

precedents_cited.case_name: Habeeb Mohammad v. State of Hyderabad
precedents_cited.relevance: Prosecution need not examine all witnesses; not bound to call unfavourable ones.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bhagwan Swarup Lal etc. etc. v. State of Maharashtra
precedents_cited.relevance: Conspiracy proved by circumstantial evidence; privacy of conspiracies.

precedents_cited.case_name: C. Bahri v. State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: No overt act needed if agreement to commit offence.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kehar Singh and Ors. v. The State (Delhi Administration)
precedents_cited.relevance: Conspiracy by circumstantial evidence; meeting of minds.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kashmira Singh v. The State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Approach to co-accused confession under S.30: other evidence first.
S.30 confession weak evidence, needs corroboration.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Gujarat v. Mohd. Atik and Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Post-arrest statements not under S.10 Evidence Act.
S.10 limited to statements during subsistence of conspiracy.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hintendra Vishnu Thakur v. State of Maharashtra
precedents_cited.relevance: Terrorist act intent to strike terror beyond law and order.

precedents_cited.case_name: Yogendra Morarji v. State of Gujarat
precedents_cited.relevance: Private defence only on reasonable apprehension.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code, 1860
statutes_cited.relevance: Conspiracy, murder, mischief by fire, common intention; convicted under 120B r/w 34, acquitted 302/34,436/34

statutes_cited.name: Terrorist and Disruptive Activities (Prevention) Act, 1987
statutes_cited.relevance: Terrorist acts by explosion/possession to strike terror; convicted

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Co-conspirator statements during agency; confessions voluntary; co-accused confession corroborative

outcome.summary: Appeals by accused-appellants against conviction and sentence under 120B IPC, Sections 3&5 Explosive Act, 3(2)(i)&3(3) TADA dismissed; convictions and life sentences upheld. State's appeal against acquittal under 302/34 & 436/34 IPC dismissed.

key_quotes.text: No religion propagates terrorism or hatred. Love for all is the basic foundation on which almost all religions are founded.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Opening observation on communal harmony and terrorism

key_quotes.text: The essence of a criminal conspiracy is the unlawful combination and ordinarily the offence is complete when the combination is framed.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines key element of conspiracy offence

key_quotes.text: Preparation and storage of bombs are per se illegal acts.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects self-defence plea, holds TADA applicable

key_quotes.text: The proper way... is, first to marshal the evidence against the accused excluding the confession altogether from consideration and see whether if it is believed, a conviction could safely be based on it.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains use of co-accused confession under S.30
